Hi Ann, thank you for the comprehensive video. When it comes to the loss of jobs, I'm in two minds about it. There have been many new technologies that have made jobs obsolete in the past and humans adapted. E.g. the invention of ploughing machines probably made human labour redundant at the time. The invention of the airplane travel probably made train ticket sales plummet. The food mixer probably killed spoon sales and took away jobs in the food industry. Food scientists who discover how to create synthetic flavors and scents probably caused producers of natural flavors and scents some losses. The cellphone killed the landline. Streaming killed cable TV. So many examples, I could go on. I think humans will adapt and hopefully new jobs will be created. The job "software developer" for e.g. was not popular or known to many just 2 or 3 decades ago, but advancements in tech have made it a job that's now in high demand. I think we will survive that aspect of it. The ethical concerns around copyright and misinformation do worry me though.

About the copyright
(overthinking alert)

Maybe, public domain artists, authors, etc and their works should not be a problem, like Van Gogh or Emily Bronte etc.

And, just a thought. Even for the living folks, you can have tags associated with the authors, and their styles. The more precise the tags, the more closer to the said person's style will generated work get. Without ever feeding any original works to the model. So when someone asks produce something in said person's style, you don't look at their original work and copy that which you are not allowed to do, you instead have tags associated with them without ever looking at their work, so you use tags for styles to produce that work, which you get by reading public domain stuff etc. For ex. if someone asks write something like a Stephen King novel, you'll write a horror, thriller, first person, suspenseful, yada-yada (it can get really precise) thing. So you are never actually writing a Stephen King novel you are just writing something that fits the same tags as Stephen's work. How precise you can get, or well picked the tags will be, depends upon how well that person has been publicly studied.

How do you get the tags without showing the original work to the models, by going through all public domain "author/artist"-like works and all public domain publishing on them. It will be miles off from what we have now, but it will be remotely ethical. But this is a long winded process and the only ethical way to do it. So did the companies we have today speedily opt to sluggishly go through this? Probably not.

When you said that the AIs can be given "access to the internet after they've been trained" and talked about that like it wasn't also training, that's not correct.  Any time an AI uses some data to improve itself, that is training.  It's not some mysterious other thing that happens "after training".  And yes, all of these AIs are trained on data from the internet, that's really the only source of data that has enough data to train models of this size.

Also, it's not possible for AI to be more accurate than humans.  The standard that it is judged by is based on how close to a human expert it can come, by definition any deviation from that standard is a failure.  We already have plenty of computers that can do things more accurately than humans - calculators, for example.  Being more accurate than humans was the whole reason to invent and use computers in the first place, and you don't need AI for that.  The purpose of AI is to train a computer to do something that computers are very bad at but humans are very good at.  In order to learn how to do those kinds of tasks, you actually have to stop relying on the reliable, deterministic parts of computer programming that make things like calculators accurate, so AIs are actually significantly less accurate than bog standard basic computer programs with no AI in them at all.
As a writer, thank you so much Ann for bringing awareness to this. It's all fun and games with AI, until real life people and their jobs and livelihood are affected.

Even if you could get AI to generate some of the grunt work of this code, you're really going to need someone to tailer it and make sure it's secure. When you are doing things for banks, software, medicine, etc, that is even more important, and a human is probably going to have to do it from the ground up. AI code can also be pretty buggy. Sort of like any other text, it's trained on data that is often flawed. I don't doubt that it will get better over time, but realistically humans will still have to be involved at some point.

I think some work will fall by the wayside with AI. There's a lot of grunt work involved in coding, and as it is, a lot of developers are sharing code on Stackexchange...pretty much no one is writing all code from the ground up, because that would be ridiculously time consuming. But there is already more work to be done in the tech world than there are developers, so if anything, it would lighten their workload. There's also a lot of middling tasks involved with software development. My husband is a developer and he's using ChatGPT to do a lot of his documentation, which is something that previously took up a lot of his time and had little reward (he still has to look it over I think). And probably a lot of things like SquareSpace (or whatever website service is en vogue later on) templates and plug-ins will be replaced by AI code rather than people writing and selling that stuff.

As you demonstrated, generative language models are not a knowledge bank. It's clear that many many people think they can use it as such. Of course it does contain knowledge, as it's trained on lots of language that contains knowledge (as well as tons of opinions and plain bulls**t), but that's more an incidental property. The model cannot differentiate between true or false. Occasionally it can produce surprisingly "insightful" results, because it is able to condense a lot text containing real knowledge into something very concise, but you cannot purposefully trigger an output like that. It's only concern is getting something that looks and sounds convincing as real human language. It does not understand anything beyond that, so even training it purely on true, factual knowledge would not guarantee truthfulness of the outcome. It's just not designed for that purpose. That doesn't mean that it's not impressive technology, and can be incredibly useful. But you have to understand how you should use it, and what the limitations are.

As for the impact of AI as a whole on employment, I think it can be large for some very specific positions/professions, but for the most part they will just be new productivity tools. Just like advanced internet search engines were when they became available. Outside of that, be very very sceptical of what the people that are trying to sell these technologies are claiming. As Adam Conover remarks in his chat with Dan Olson: They are just trying to become the winners in this new tech hype, like with the crypto and metaverse hypes before this, and they will just make up things in order to increase the hype.

Overall, a rational and accurate reading of the pros and cons of AI and the way it may be used for good or ill.  I also noted that the narrative drifted toward a common misunderstanding about these AI systems.  The monologue several times referred to AI systems "knowing" things.  This is a common metaphor we use to simply describe the behavior of complex systems, but for AI, it encourages the misconception that AI systems are sentient beings with self-awareness and a theory of mind.  This is further encouraged by the name we give to these systems, implying actual intelligence when all they are is highly sophisticated pattern-generation engines.  This sophistication plays upon the tendency of humans to identify presence of an intelligent entity based on the recognition of certain patterns.

Finally, a good, balanced, non-fear-mongery take on AI.  <3 This is why we love you.  :)

I'm an animator, and I think AI will be a beneficial tool for artistic industries, so long as that law that AI art is exempt from copyright.  

I kinda see it in a similar light to motion capture.  We were all afraid that would displace our jobs, but it didn't.   Once we could output significantly more animations, the scope of what our jobs were increased substantially.  An old video game from the 90s would maybe have 50 animations, but now we have thousands per character.  I think the same will happen for concept artists and the like.  

As for contract artists, if AI can't be copyright, then they are safe as well.  Sure, we're all playing with midjourney, but as you pointed out, it can't get exactly what you want or collaborate.  There are better programs for this, but learning how to do them well and utilizing them takes just as much time as a contract artist would.  Instead those artists could absorb that knowledge then use AI to do a quick pass for feedback before exerting real time and effort into their final peice.

I asked ChatGPT which kind of jobs could not be replaced by AI and/or robots. This was the answer:

While the advancement of AI and robotics has the potential to automate various jobs, there are still several occupations that are less likely to be replaced completely by machines in the foreseeable future. These jobs often require a combination of technical skills, creativity, emotional intelligence, and physical dexterity. Here's a list of jobs that are considered less likely to be replaced by AI and/or robots:

  1.  Therapists/Counselors: The human element of empathy, understanding, and emotional support is crucial in therapy and counseling sessions.

 2.   Social Workers: The ability to navigate complex social situations, provide emotional support, and advocate for individuals and communities is a fundamental aspect of social work.

  3.  Teachers: Educators play a vital role in shaping young minds, providing individualized instruction, and adapting to diverse learning styles, which requires human intuition and adaptability.

 4.   Artists: Creativity and the ability to express emotions and ideas through various art forms are unique to human beings, making artistic occupations less likely to be replaced.

  5.  Writers/Authors: Crafting engaging stories, persuasive content, and complex narratives with a human touch requires creativity, intuition, and a deep understanding of emotions.

 6.   Entrepreneurs: The ability to identify opportunities, innovate, and adapt business strategies in response to market changes is an essential skill that requires human decision-making.

 7.   Healthcare Professionals: While AI and robotics can assist in healthcare, occupations such as doctors, surgeons, nurses, and caregivers involve critical thinking, empathy, and complex decision-making that are best suited for human practitioners.

 8.   Scientists/Researchers: The process of scientific discovery, experimentation, and analysis often involves creativity, hypothesis formation, and adapting research methodologies, which are currently challenging for AI systems.

  9.  Police Officers/Detectives: Law enforcement professionals rely on intuition, judgment, and the ability to navigate complex social situations, making their roles less likely to be fully automated.

 10.   Skilled Tradespeople: Professions such as plumbers, electricians, carpenters, and locksmiths require hands-on expertise, problem-solving skills, and adaptability to different work environments.

  11.  Personal Care Assistants: Assisting individuals with daily activities, providing companionship, and offering emotional support often require human connection and empathy.

  12.  Event Planners: Organizing and coordinating events involve personalization, understanding client preferences, and managing unexpected situations, which can be challenging for AI systems.

It's important to note that while these jobs are less likely to be fully replaced by AI and robotics, technological advancements may still augment these professions and change the nature of the work involved. Adaptability and a willingness to learn new skills will continue to be valuable in the evolving job market.

The term "hallucinating" is very misleading, because it suggests something "weird", while in reality generative models do that all the time - that's exactly the way they work. For example ChatGPT generates text word by word, using probability of words appearing in given sequence. So it's always "making stuff up", however since it pick the most probable words (where the probability comes from the training sets), it will often make sense. We only notice issue when the training set didn't have enough inputs, so the results are clearly random. But it's important to understand that every response is always "hallucinated".

This break through in 'AI' to me, is just making people think about what is the difference between learning from a source and stealing from a source?

As a musician I feel that people 'steal' from other artists all the time already. If I have a student that plays nothing but Green Day, what kind of music do you thing they would write? Probably will sound a lot like Green Day, and as long as one note is different we will say, it's completely original! 
Now though people say if an AI was trained on Green Day albums, and then writes a song that sounds like Green Day, it's stealing. With this mentality, Ann herself is stealing from any cook that came before her and made anything close to what she made. Case and point, if Ann makes and sells a chocolate cake, no one says she's stealing from the person who invented the chocolate cake. Instead we assume Ann learned how to make a cake, and then made one herself. We also know that in baking measurements are precise, and so again this could be considered stealing if you have to use the exact measurements to get the same cake, instead of Ann having to change at least one ingredient to make it her own recipe.

So again I ask, what is the real difference between learning from a source, and stealing from that source? If the answer is to make one small change and call it your own, then I want to call into conversation the definition of creativity.

8:14 Transformative works are not always "okay" in all cases. They can be okay under some conditions as long as a photo or source material has become unrecognizable from the original work. Even then, derivative works can still be considered copyright infringement if the original author recognizes it. If a photo of a person's likeness is used, even if placed in an oil painted style or water color style, that's still considered copyright infringement.

The copyright issue gets even more murky. If the work has been placed under such copyleft schemes such as Creative Commons licenses, some of which don't allow for transformations at all, then AI tools like Midjourney are producing works which may be considered copyright infringement.

It also matters how the work may be used. If the AI work will be used to generate money for someone other than the copyright holder (i.e., used for commercial purposes), it's much more likely to be considered infringing.

Because we don't know how tools like ChatGPT and Midjourney have been trained and on what underlying source materials, the only way to know if an AI generated image is considered copyright infringement is to be taken to a court of law. For example, if you were to ask for a cartoon character in the style of Mickey Mouse, it's pretty much guaranteed that if the resulting AI image looks anything like Disney's character, Disney will sue you for its use.

YouTube's AI is 100% memory based. I experimented with it for a few years. It can only suggest future recommendations if it can see previous ones. If watch history is erased recommendations will be 100% wrong. If watch history is changed new recommendations will be based on new parametres in this changed watch history. It uses search history as well. Everything you search on YouTube and on Google in general both on your PC and phone. I noticed that it also has ability to watch through the camera and listen through the microphone especially on iPhone. I would repeat a phrase few times into the microphone such as "hearing aids" and within couple hours I was inundated with ads for hearing aids. I am a noise sensitive Autistic with hypersonsory perception and start hearing at a negative 18 Db and have 1 mile hearing range. Needless to say I do not require hearing aids :)))))) I would then change the phrase and the ads would change. If you say "abuse" or "murder" you will be soon inundated with criminal news. If you say "suicide" 988 recommendations will start popping up. I think YouTube AI has same ability as we Autistics have - memory and observation based pattern recognition.

I'll agree that AI is most likely doing more damage than good at the moment, but I'll argue that it's being blown wayyyyyy out of proportion. It's just another tool that's been invented that shakes things up, but it's shaking up multiple industries at the same time is why it's getting so much attention (that plus the power of social media). 
Back in the 80s, when AutoCAD was invented, drafters were furious and up the creek without a paddle. Why? Because management thought their engineers could now just "push a button" and everything was done. So the drafters got canned, the years go by, management finally realizes now that everything is a mess, and they have to train their engineers to use AutoCAD properly, and now the engineers are completely overworked.

Fast forward some more years, CAD (in general, not just AutoCAD) gets so advanced, that it becomes its own entire skillset. Even today there's still people/management that think engineers can just push a button and have a proper, fully functional three-dimensional parametric model to use for manufacturing. In truth, they can't. It's too much for an engineer to do on top of everything else they do. It's an entire skill set of its own if you want it done properly. 

But we don't need people drawing with pencils and protractors anymore in that line of work. 

Lots of people are going to lose their jobs due to bad management, not AI.

I dont know if he gets mentioned or not, and i really wish id saved the video, but Hank green made a really important observation about AI and I can only try my best to paraphrase. We're not even finished defining the "rules" about the internet, and discovering its uses and where lines should be drawn. Now we've got AI to compound that, and things are going to get ugly and messy while we try to sort out what the rules are, where the boundaries are and what crossing them would look like (and the consequences of doing so).

Eventually, there'll be a system of sorts built around it, and we'll know how to navigate, but thats gonna be years. Until then, expect things to be very confusing and VERY messy.

I would like to add a point to the copyright section. I'm unaware if it has been solved but because of how copyright works, technically nobody owns the art (imagine, text, etc.) that ai puts out. For something to be protected by copyright there has to be human authorship behind the work, and obviously ai programs aren't human. 

It's kinda in the same vein as commissioning someone. You describe what you want to an artist who creates the work, then you pay them. This payment is both for the work, the artists time, and certain rights to the piece that you're discussed with the artist prior. When giving an ai a prompt, you're not paying for anything. Not the work, not the time, and most definitely not the rights. So, if you use an ai to design a logo, for example, if someone else were to like that design and decided to use it for their own use, you wouldn't really have a case because you don't own the image. 

Again, I don't know if a 'solution' has come up, but I personally find it a bit cathartic how ai people scoff at arists bringing up copyright to protect their works, but then failing to have the same protection for "their" work lol

I think it's time we recognize what "training" an AI actually is. Training is a good description of how we interact with an ai model, to shape it into so something that does what we want.

What we are technically doing, however, is "encoding" the training data into the model. The encoding, by its nature, is lossy, but it is a type of encoding nonetheless. 

If we look at it this way, I believe issues of copyright and ownership becomes much clearer; and we can focus on deciding how much of an original work you can actually copy and encode before you leave the realm of fair use.

Another two issues include:
1) Privacy - If someone uses AI to analyse "big data", does that mean that the data has now been uploaded to the AI's database and is available for future uses by that AI?  That might contravene various privacy laws.
2) Indemnity - The T&Cs for ChatGPT that you accept states that the user will indemnify ChatGPT/OpenAI for all legal claims.  That means that you will need to pay for lawyers to defend OpenAI and pay for any damages yourself if anyone takes you or OpenAI to court over something you've done or misinformation from OpenAI that you've published.

Something people should be aware of and think about with regards to the training of AI... that is almost exactly how human artists are trained.  Show up and ask someone who has never seen a pencil sketch or a watercolor or the type of dog you're asking about and ask them to create the same images and they, too, will fail utterly.  By showing them many examples of other peoples work, they start to learn what is meant by 'pencil sketch' and 'dog' and such.  The way this learning occurs is that neurons in the brain are 'trained' by having their activation thresholds change.  The way a deep learning AI system is trained, the learning occurs by adjusting activation thresholds of nodes in a big network very similar to the network of neurons in your brain.  If the AI is committing copyright infringement - then so are you.  As for giving permission, the permission has been given by making the works publicly available.  There is a very simple way to prevent AI or other artists from learning your style or perceiving your work - don't distribute it.  

Misinformation is an old problem, and it's a problem that we have faced before.  Every single time new communication mediums were developed, for instance, there were concerns about what was being communicated and whether it was guaranteed to always be entirely truthful.  From permitting the general public to learn to read and write, to the printing press, to telephones, TV, and, of course, the Internet, every single one was greeted with questions about how anyone could trust the information communicated.  While this certainly doesn't mean that it's not a problem, it's just one that we figured out the answer to a very long time ago.  The audience has to use critical thinking to evaluate everything they read and see.  That has always been the solution, and while a million different attempts have made to come up with some way that audiences could avoid ever learning critical thinking skills or using them but still be protected from misinformation, every one fails.  Critical thinking is, and has been for a very long time, absolutely necessary to avoid becoming lost in a sea of confusion.  That was true even before the introduction of the printing press.

It's not really true at all that "we have no transparency at the moment as to what data it was trained on."  We have great transparency on most of it.  For instance, for ChatGPT, the data it was trained on was a dataset called openwebtext originally, and then further training was done on other datasets, all of which are entirely publicly available.  There are some parts of ChatGPT that are not publicly available, but those aren't the training dataset, they are things OpenAI paid for like in order to train ChatGPT to not produce offensive or dangerous content, it hired a bunch of people to talk to an early version of ChatGPT and flag any responses that were problematic.  I think it was around 1,000 people they had do this.  Then they created a separate AI trained to recognize responses that seemed similar to the flagged responses, and used that to adjust ChatGPT to not produce output like that and instead produce messages like "I can't give information about cooking crystal meth" instead of just giving a recipe.  That part is mostly not available, but OpenAI published a whole bunch of research papers explaining exactly how they did every part of it.  If you have a couple million dollars and want to reproduce their work, it wouldn't be that difficult.  And this is true of most of the AI systems we have seen so far - they are very public about their datasets (most are available on a website called HuggingFace) and techniques, you can find a mountain of research papers on ArXiv.org.  

I would be careful saying that the court decision we have seen so far are good news for graphic designers.... Because of the way they wrote the court decision, if you use any tool that uses any kind of AI at any part of the process of creating an image, the whole work would not be permitted to be copyrighted.  And Adobe Photoshop is integrating a bunch of AI features.  I predict that court decision will be modified, but so far, its still legally unclear.

I remember a few videos ago you mentioned the difference between *dis*information (spreading deliberate falsehoods) and *mis*information (spreading information that is wrong because you think it's right). 
In this video you've effectively said that AI is capable of doing both those things.

Bad actors could get AI to, as you say, make deliberate falsehoods seem convincing, and perhaps even engineer versions of AI without as much regulation that are specifically used for misleading people (which would be the far worse *dis*information).

But much more commonly, because an AI "confidently makes stuff up" when a question is asked that the AI's dataset doesn't directly answer, it's evidently possible that someone will innocently believe such a "made-up" answer to be true and then go on to mistakenly spread that information (which would be *mis*information).

This is a great video for those who are unknowledgeable on the subject.  That being said, I had three concerns on the copyright aspect:

1.) What's stopping someone or a company from "touching up" the AI-generated work to claim it as their own?  As a professional animator & illustrator myself, I've heard about similar things happening in the pastâ€” not specifically with AI, but with other people's handiwork.  The script of the original "Alien" film was a notorious example in this industry, where some producers tried to steal the script by simply changing character names from the original credited writers

2.) If a company decides to create their own AI-generator, then call themselves as an artistic entity created by a human, could they circumvent the definition and therefore label their "artworks" under copyright?

3.) Does copyright even matter when someone or a company can simply purchase a trademark of their creationsâ€” or however the legal system works in claiming ownership of something? I have a feeling we are going to have to temporarily regress to in-class written exams, because all of the things we've moved to the virtual world now (which is, frankly, easier for both instructors and students) can't be consistently connected to the student.

On the other hand, my dad, who also teaches, loves AI because he can generate quick reference pages for his students from his own notes outlines.

Related to misinformation/opacity of data sets, I work in a library that works in tandem with our k-12 school system, where teaching media literacy is becoming very important . We were interested in seeing if Chat GPT could cite sources, since acknowledging and being able to check where you got information is a huge part of media literacy. 

Short answer is that it cannot;  It either will spit out citations for sources that do not exist or flat out says it just came up with its answer based on what it has been trained on.

The thing about "X technology is going to destroy jobs" is that there are always more jobs that can be done, and it's not like you're ordained at birth to be only suitable for a certain job. Some of my dad's ancestors were put out of work by some of my mom's ancestors when the powered loom was invented and hand-weaving became obsolete. But that doesn't mean my dad is unemployed - he's a computer programmer, a job that didn't exist in the past. And while you might be able to do the work of 50 employees with only one with a new technology, that doesn't necessarily mean 49 fewer jobs, more often it means 50 times the production. New technology means jobs change, not that there are fewer jobs altogether.

Yes, AI can become a huge problem, not just for lost jobs, or copyright issues. They are teaching AI to lie about certain things, which is a huge problem, especially for children or adults who will just believe whatever the AI says, without researching the topic themselves. There's also the possibility that children can start having AI friends instead of real friends. Adults can have fake AI relationships instead of real ones, or be involved with AI porn, or even deep fake porn. There are deep fakes that can ruin reputations, and even create legal problems for people. What happens if some bad actor decides to make a convincing deep fake of someone showing that person committing a crime? Or even a recording of their voice confessing to the crime? The courts haven't caught up to that technology yet, and then it would be up to the accused to prove that they aren't guilty or that it isn't actually them in the video or recording. That moves the "innocent until proven guilty" to "guilty until proven innocent." Even if they can get out of criminal charges, it could still ruin their reputation, cost them their job, and who knows what else. This could be used to sway elections, or to smear political opponents. Even creating fake accounts with AI can be used to sway elections or to spread misinformation or propaganda. Then there's the problem that it could start making people dumber. There's already evidence that technology has made people dumber, because if you don't use your brain, if you can just ask google a question instead of thinking about it, or remembering answers, if you can use google maps to find your way around, instead of trying to remember the way, it makes you dumber. If you use technology instead of actually using your brain, it negatively affects your brain. There's also evidence that scrolling has negatively affected people's attention spans. All of these are big problems, especially since technology is addictive, in a way. It's a distracting and a way to avoid real life, but it doesn't actually make you happier. It actually distracts you from things that could make you happier. 
There are a lot of potential problems with AI, and that's before we ever even get close to true AI (AI that is actually sentient).
With AI voices we are no longer going to believe everything we hear online, on TV, on radio, or over the phone ever again. Scammers can fake a kidnapping ransom by mimicking the voices of loved ones.
ChatGPT cannot/will not cite its sources for factual claims. Try asking it.

There's an image model called Mitsua Diffusion that's been trained on only public domain / volunteered images. It's leagues behind what things like Midjourney can produce, of course, but it does mean that there are people who are beginning to think about how to create these AIs in an ethical way. That does not address the full range of issues with the technology, but it does address most of the concerns from artists. I wonder if we might start seeing similar models in the future that disclose all of their training data and have gone to great lengths to ensure that it is free of copyright or licensing issues.

As an aside, I definitely appreciate the down-to-earth approach here, rather than fearmongering about AI's capabilities. As it stands, AIs are rudimentary at best, and can only excel at very specific things. The problem isn't that AI is smart, it's that humans don't know how to deal with it. And with AI-generated nonsense potentially polluting future AI training data, it might spell trouble for the capabilities of future AI. But we'll have to see where that goes. For the time being, humanity's most dangerous threat is still humanity itself.

I think that one of the more pressing dangers of AI is for students. The students see: oh, I have to write an essay on this topic. They don't see the point of the exercise, that is to read, understand, summarize and produce an essay someone can read and understand. This assignment is meant to train the students brain in all those steps. They go to AI and get it done fast. That is not new, teachers have been getting copy/paste from Wikipedia or the internet for decades now, but it was very easy to spot. Even if the student just re-worded wikipedia, some of the desired training was being done. 

Back in my day, the assignment was to hand copy the information from an Enciclopedia. You ended up summarizing just to write less and even if you didn't you still got the benefit of being forced to look at the text very closely by hand copying it. Was it boring? Yes. But often boredom is the mother of exploration - I'd end up reading up on other stuff on the same volume just to get a break from the task at hand.

I heard "in its database" in this video, didn't I? That's a common misconception. These AI models do not have anything in them that could be called a database or even memory. They were trained to generate text or images that look like the training data, i.e. they get a prompt and generate something, then they get either rewarded or punished based on how much their output matches the training data.

This means that generating AIs don't have any idea what facts are. They know how to generate a result that fits the question somewhat well. If it was something they encountered often during their training, the result naturally matches the training data closely on both form and content. If it was more rare, the result matches in form only.

I think it's important to keep in mind as well that AI should not be abolished entirely, as there are some ethical applications for it that are really useful. for example, I as a musician have been using singing synthesizers for my music for a long time as I love the unique vocal textures and the ability to carefully configure the voice to do whatever I want. The software I currently use the most, synthesizerV, utilizes AI trained models for the databases in conjunction with the traditional concatentative synthesis method to produce a result that sounds more realistic. This allows the musician that is using that vocal instrument to be able to spend less time making the voice sound realistic and more time making the voice sound more expressive and emotional. All of the input and creativity still has to come from the artist, as it still just functions like a regular instrument where entering the melody and adjusting Dynamics and different aspects of the vocal instrument is entirely up to the user, but the AI model allows for the voice to sound more realistic with a less intense amount of effort, leading to better creativity.

I love this channel.  Ann, you're such a great source of information and entertainment.  You have a wonderful ability to explain things to a wide audience, young and old, without and skipping on too much fundamental detail. 

I work in an organisation that provides customer services and has a large IT department.  Late last year, I thought in the next 5 years AI would replace a large portion of knowledge based jobs that are non-life-critical, do not pose significant profit risk, and that currently utilise a good company knowledge database (eg. Call centre role).  AI software may be able to replace non-senior/non-expert roles in these cases.  AI would handle 75% of the usual customer enquiries, and refer the 25% complex enquiries to a senior/expert. Complex enquiries being those typically involving a clerical or system issue.  

I still think this may happen, but maybe not as quickly and as smoothly. 

Companies will be motivated by a substantial cost saving with an acceptable level of risk.  The risk being difficulty interacting with the AI, or inaccurate advice or poor resolution.  Similar to the early days of voice recognition systems.  

However eventually the level of AI customer service would be, at worst, the same level of  human error.  But most likey better, with more accuracy and consistency in advice and actions, and less wait time on the phone or chat.  

The first few years of emergence will be a bit dodgy, as the first adopters may be companies desperate to make savings, without the financial or technical capability to deliver and quickly improve or maintain a quality AI system.  

But companies that want savings, but are a little more risk adverse, will spend a bit more time to develop a well-functioning AI before letting it loose on their customer base.  For the first one or two years they will probably support it with their current staff, until it is proven reliable.  At which point then they will start redeploying staff to other roles, or reduce staff numbers.  

Also at which point, they probably will have invested so much time and money that it will be difficult to decide to abandon.  After all, going back to 100% human customer service probably also means a return to lengthy call/chat wait times.  Not good when your competitors are still answering within a few minutes, not in 20.  And you might think you'd rather wait to interact with a human, rather than an AI.  But also remeber that you probably currently hate waiting 20 minutes just for someone to answer - not knowing if they will be helpful and correctly provide what your needing.

On another point - I think the fastest thing we'll see AI make  an impact on is document editing.  AI is already being embedded into email and document software, like Outlook and Word.  It'll offer improvements like a spell checker, such as suggesting better phrasing, tone etc.  Everyone will be able to spell correctly and write like a scholar!  Which raises the question: will reliance on that make us better or worse?  Worse, in that you won't need proper writing skills to sound brilliant, and in a way is kind of fake?  Or better, in that seeing the suggestions provides you with feedback, constant coaching, by which you will learn and become better day by day?

As both an artist and a programmer I don't mind AI at all. In fact I use ChatGPT near daily.

I for one don't see the argument of AI leaning from copyrighted images as much of a problem. As an artist I learned from and copied many other artists styles. That's just how it is. As long as it's not a direct copy of the original work it's fine. I also don't think you should have the option of opting out of the training if your work is accessible online. If I want I could download an artists work and teach myself to copy their style and it's 100% legal. I don't see how AI should be treated different.

As a programmer I LOVE ChatGPT. If I'm stumped I can ask it to debug my code and it finds my problem within seconds. I can also ask it to create a code segment, or even a full method. The time is has saved me is immense.

I really feel that students using Chat GPT for their homework are being super lazy and dumb. Teachers and professors already know what they're instructing students on, so, who really benefits from learning and doing homework? What are they supposed to learn if an AI does the work for them? Why do they even pay for education, then?

The solution to people losing their jobs has always been large scale reforms to keep people from losing safety and security dependant on having a job - this wouldn't solve every problem, and its a long term goal, and I don't say it as a way to dismiss the pressing economic realities and anxiety and issues happening in the now. But it's not just jobs AI replaces -- if we promised people safety and their needs met, people fighting against shutting down coal plants would have much less leverage. Bosses that abuse their workers would have much less leverage. If someone gets sick, or has to stay home to care for a loved one, they would be safe and secure. Some people think that if everyone could have their basic needs met, no one would work at all, and thus nothing would get done. I disagree with this in general, studies of UBI pilot programs also disagree with this - people tend to go into training or education and often end up with better employment instead. But in a field like art, I really disagree with it. People create art without monetary incentive all the time. Obviously, artists deserve to be paid for their work. But the idea that art itself would disappear from human creation if no one HAD to create art to eat is silly to me.

AI feels like a tool to me. Tools can be used to assist people and make their jobs easier, increase their output, or automate things they don't want to do. Before these tools,  sometimes these things were still outsourced (and may or may not have been compensated to the person it was outsourced too) -- many of the great master painters had studios full of assistance whose names no one knows who painted huge amounts of their famous canvases. The names of editors are often lost to history, though many professional editors will tell you some of the most famous literary styles come more from the editor desk than the writer whose names you know. We already have artists using premade assets to make backgrounds - some more ethically sourced than others. We already have animators who use AI assisted software to track movements. These are still art, even as jobs may have been lost in the changing way things work. You can get completely free open source rigging now, and let the AI light a full scene with a click. I am not saying thats the same thing as using midjourney to make a whole painting, but I'm not sure I know where the line is or why its there. If someone uses an AI to make 20 pictures and then collages those images into a very human directed scene, are we back in the realm of human art? I cannot say. What if they paint over it? Distort it? Alter it in photoshop? Simply use it as a reference for a freehand painting? If a writer uses a writing software to correct their typos, or to replace a word they overuse - that's still a human writer. If a writer puts their stream of consciousness quick draft with dialogue and beats in, and the AI writes a second draft of that, and then a human edits that, is that still human writing? I'm less clear.

And its strange to see people dismissing other work - especially things we have kind of arbitrary decided are crafts rather than 'proper art' as "different" --  lace making is a famous one -- as if the labor and time expertise and traditions and training that go into trades are lesser expressions of humanity. Anyone who has ever watched one of those old compilation videos of prep kitchen workers or street venues moving at astounding speed to the beat of a radio should understand the things we traditionally view as elevated are, in some sense, pretty arbitrary. So should we not automate fruit slicing? Or should we hope for a world where everyone can gain artistry where they desire to, with the security and freedom and tools to do it?

This is why I'm glad this video mentioned radiologists and data analysis - both jobs where were created in the last 100 years and could be forever altered or changed beyond our current recognition by AI. But there are also jobs being automated away that maybe should be? A fully automated amazon warehouse would cost millions of jobs. Does that mean we shouldn't try to replace all that bending and sorting and lifting with machines if we could? It's a very complicated situation, and I understand the impulse to say "no, manual labor is different than artistic labor", I really do, but I think some of what we call one and not the other is culturally influenced and biased as well. I don't claim to have the answers

I know this is ideological and long term and doesn't address the real loss of income and security people are facing. I'm just trying to figure out what the best way to get those things back is, and if fighting automation is that.

Bias in AI generation shows up in lots of interesting ways! I was conducting a silly little experiment with Dall-E a few months ago, I was attempting to see if I could identify any unique traits, or, any tells of the artists' who's works had been used to generate them by repeatedly running queries on specialized prompts. I did so by using long prompts, specifying very specific fandoms on the internet to try and narrow the pool of data that it had generate off of. I was generating sci-fi themed images, and one of my tests was for characters from a kid's show I watched in the 90's, Beasties, or, Beast Wars - see, in Canada, at the time, no children's show could have the word "war" in the title, so, outside of Canada, it was known as "Beast Wars," and for me, it was "Beasties." I generated a swath of images from the latter, and the images I got were fairly stock sci-fi images; lots of blue backgrounds, with the characters highlighted in neon light - very Cyberpunk. When I changed "Beasties" to "Beast Wars," however, that changed instantly. All the characters I received were looking off into the distance, chest puffed out, with heavenly clouds in the background, and golden light rays streaking past them. They were all, consistently, images of glory, the kind of thing you see in things meant to deify warfare. It's nothing huge or game-changing, just one of those things that made me really think on these AI apps, and the ethics of them.

It is also very important and dangerous concern that people are using AI to make fake p0rn videos / images of people without their concern, let alone create that content with minors as a request. This is the part that scares me the most.
About that "we're not there yet" at the end of the video... consider how fast we went from DALLâ€¢E to what we have now.

Funny (and true) story about AI and drones.  The military has been testing AI run drones in simulators.  An AI is supposed to designate targets, a human operator is supposed to greenlight the target(s) or designate them as non-targets, and then the AI is to take out the greenlit targets and none of the non-targets.  The AI wants to score well, valid targets are positive points and non-targets are negative points. 
Well ... the AI drone killed its human operator and then killed all available targets (in the virtual simulation).  You see, according to AI logic, to achieve maximized points, it had to take out the human operator who designated certain targets as off-limits and created conditions that would create negative points.  Presto!  AI created a maximum points scenario.  
That freaked out the military officer who was talking (off the record) to a reporter about it.

The story you were talking about around 13:30 is something I knew for a long time.  My entire Master's Thesis was all about explaining how biases in your training dataset could screw up machine learning algorithms.  I was doing speaker verification and the training data was entirely based off of English speakers.  And I was able to show just how poorly it was able to understand someone talking another language.  In fact, if the person they were trying to identify wasn't speaking English and the speech sample it was being compared again was speaking a different non-English language it literally never got that right.

I published my Master's Thesis back in 2012.

What worries me most about AI isn't the job replacement, singularity, or copywrite issues. I think the worst part about it is that AI threatens to replace CREATIVITY itself. People can easily fall for the convenience it offers. Why learn to draw when an AI can do it for you? Why learn to write, when an AI can do it for you?

To create art is a journey, it's a wonderful feeling to make things. Getting good at an instrument. Finishing a thoughtful essay or script. Cooking a delicious meal for your family. The quality of that music, writing, cooking, etc. isn't all that AI cannot replicate. It cannot give you a feeling of TRUE satisfaction.

While the outcome of art is fantastic, and I do love a good song, book, meal, etc. those are all just products, and I don't believe we should treat art (or care about it) for what it yields, but the joy it brings to produce. We are human, we were meant to express ourselves, having evolved to communicate using complex language, and making art on cave walls. AI is a quick and easy way to get the product, without the journey and self-expression.

In my opinion, you miss out on a big part of life itself, by letting  an AI create something for you. That brain is a muscle, use it or lose it.

Lastly, AI has no love for anything, even if it became advanced to mimic it, there's no hormones responsible for love, a machine cannot feel. If a Grandma bakes you cookies, you know she does it with LOVE. If a robot made you cookies, there is no love behind that. Same goes for making AI create artwork of your pet. An AI feels nothing when it looks at an image of a kitten, puppy, etc... how are people okay with this?

The use of AI can be problematic and insulting to others, but I think it's equally insulting to the self (if not more so). As humans, we should remember we are alive. We DO feel. An AI cannot make something because it loves you, it cannot be your friend, you deprive yourself of true connection by using it. Creation is an expression of love, I believe. A selfless expression (generally). We sing to express ourselves, and it brings people together because we resonate with those feelings. We cook for those we care about. We procreate because we see the beauty of life, and wish for it to thrive and persevere, like it always does.

The AI artwork problem is massively concerning for artists because artists already struggle a LOT from a multitude of issues outside of AI, and this includes people trying to steal and grift from their work, AI just makes it easier.

People have been reselling patreon content or straight up giving out for free for years. Artists have to deal with their works being stolen and traced or recoloured with thieves claiming they have created that work themselves and often need to take action against these people to make them stop - hell I myself had someone steal and lazily draw over an old sketch of mine on Discord, despite the WIP of my image being 2 posts above it, and the thief panicking and just disappearing once confronted about it.

The freelance artist market is heavily stacked and still growing, and artists are constantly underselling their work to remotely get their business off the ground (especially when compared to industry standards and salaries.) AI art does nothing but flood an already saturated market with, what in my opinion, is essentially digital forgeries that undervalue the actual work and skill that goes into making art. They solely focus on the outcome and product of the art and never the process or fun that goes into making it. And whilst some AI outcomes can be easy to tell if their made using AI, that argument is not going to hold up for long, and it already isn't. PLENTY of AI users (especially furry related ones) on twitter are mass producing artwork that look nigh indistinguishable from actual pieces. There are already many dramas and communities that are turning on legitimate artists under the suspicion their works may be done by AI when they aren't.

And no, learning how to use the programs to produce AI art barely compares to actually learning to draw - using a bunch of code made by someone else, that rearranges noise and pixels from existing assets stolen from the works of others does not make you an "artist." If you know how to mod games like Minecraft or a Fallout game, you can easily figure out how to use Stable Diffusion locally on your computer through process of mucking around and finding out what settings and prompts works best. That is never going to be a comparable substitute for learning all the art fundamentals, years of practice and studying to actually be able to draw, paint, model, animate, etc.

Most artists can't even fight for the copyright of their own work like the music industry can because we can't afford to toss around lawsuits everywhere, especially the younger lot in the freelancer crowd. A lot of us are just average people trying to get by, so when we see our work stolen we just have to kinda call it out in public/online and hope they stop out of guilt on their consciousness (which never happens, because they'll usually just grift from another artists work instead or just rebrand under a new account.)

And just,
us artists don't need "AI art programs" that make stuff for us, because artists literally pride themselves on making things. We love the process, thats why we literally do it lmao. We have been using AI tools for a pretty long time to create shortcuts and make processes easier, such as CSP with the pose or hand scanner that makes the posing of 3D models easier, or interpolation for animators on programs like Cacani, but they never automatically make the things for us because that takes half the fun out of art; MAKING IT. So the people who benefit from AI art generators are literally grifters and commissioners who want something made on the fly

I'm an author, and AI has definitely been a big topic in the writing community.

I am not worried about AI becoming a better novelist than me. However, I am concerned with the market. A few problems off the top of my head:

1. **Competition.** If you see an AI book or an ad for one, that is a space in the search results that could have gone to an actual author.

One can generate and publish a short AI book in a week or less. That's a LOT of added competition. Publishing is a highly competitive market alreadyâ€”it's *really difficult* to get visibility. Authors shouldn't have to deal with getting drowned out by AI.

2. **Low-quality books pushing consumers away from buying indie.** Self-publishing gets a bad rap because, let's be real, lots of them are awful. Many people refuse to buy indie for this reason. However, the market has seen a rise in quality indie books as professional resources and knowledge on publishing have become widely available.

But here's the thing: AI books suck and readers want a story told by a human. But not all "authors" who publish AI books are transparent about that. They're just going to show up on Amazon as an indie book.

If there's an issue with buying AI books without knowing until it's too late, people may get sick of it and avoid anything self-published so they don't get scammed.

3. **Authors unintentionally/unknowingly using AI.** There was recently an author who has gotten hate and boycotts over her book cover containing AI art. What many people don't know is that traditionally-published authors (as this woman was) don't get a say in their cover.

This was completely on the publishing company, but she's now getting the blame.

Furthermore, I also recently saw an indie author who paid a cover artist...not knowing they used AI art for the book cover. He then got dragged for it.

People can be vile. Review bombing and a smeared reputation can drive an author into the ground in a way they may never recover from.

It's already causing problems, and I unfortunately have a feeling it will only get worse.

It's amusing to me that a food scientist on a food related channel can present the situation with more veracity than media outlets that are actually focused on tech. Great video that will hopefully help many people get somewhat of a clearer picture on the situation. Some notes of input I'd like to add:

AI _unintentionally_ training on AI generated output is actually a good thing in terms of avoiding misinformation because generation loss will ultimately lead to AI just spitting out complete gibberish making it functionally useless. I say _unintentionally_ because part of training generative models like midjourney involves AI training on AI generated output.

For job loss, current gen AI is incapable of replacing talent or highly skilled work. Taking programming as an example, ChatGPT is actually very bad at it even though it can create convincing output that might fool an unskilled programmer. Competent software businesses aren't going to be replacing programmers with AI any time soon, though there is a great risk that the industry will face a shortage of skilled programmers as new programmers perceive ChatGPT to be an useful tool for learning (it is not). In terms of art, the artists most at risk are concept artists, where the art is not intended as the end product, but rather a guide for ideas.

Plagiarism is an issue however, both for art and word as you have pointed out, and even in the programming world as AI has no knowledge of software licenses and will happily spit out stolen code without crediting the author.

All in all, properly designed and utilized AI _is_ a good thing for humanity, and must inevitably replace jobs (as much technological development has throughout history) if humanity is to progress sustainably. The real challenge is shifting the economy to ensure that such developments don't result in widening class divides and amplifying poverty. If done properly, tech can help humanity *end* poverty, and AI is no exception, but that really relies on having competent legislators who understand the tech and are willing to enact in the public interest. The greatest problem humanity faces is still political. We don't have to worry about hyper intelligent AI any time soon because current gen AI is still little more than a novelty that can do fancy tricks. While we are getting a better understanding of the broader mechanics of cognition, intelligence is still largely a mysterious black box. The fundamental concepts behind AI haven't progressed much, we simply have the computing power to build larger models now.

Barring a more natural cataclysm, advanced AI will come some day though, so humanity should use this time to adapt shape developments in the right direction, in favour of broader human interests than the profits of a minority.

Another ethical concern with AI, especially in the field of data analysis and diagnostics is the question of who is responsible for the conclusions AIs arrive at, and eventual errors those conclusions might contain. If an AI misdiagnoses you, who is responsible? The AI can't be held accountable, it's not a living thing. So then, is it the company who developed the AI? Is it the administration who approved the AI to provide diagnoses instead of a human professional? Is it, if there is one, the human supervisor of thr AI? We discussed this at length in our university courses (I'm doing my masters degree in psychology) and we could not reach a satisfactory conclusion. Of course, it's not like erroneous diagnoses/treatments don't happen with human care providers, far from it, but at least in that case it is a /little/ more traceable when and how the error occurred and which individuals may be held responsible.

The copyright problem really doesn't bother me as much as it bothers others. Sorry, not sorry. Blatant copying is wrong, I'll agree there. But if anyone's going to suggest that taking inspiration from someone else's work is wrong? Then every architect and their work should be destroyed, every painting after the first artist who ever painted should be fined down to the 50th generation and their work destroyed, every written copyrighted work after the first written work should be destroyed and the author fined to the 50th generation, etc etc etc. Everything is inspired by something or someone else's already existing work.
There are people who are so highly skilled with a pencil that they can replicate a photograph - should they face copyright bs from the camera company/artist who took a photograph?
There are people who can near-perfectly replicate Van Gogh's painting styles - should they face copyright bs for doing so?
Anyone who thinks "yes" to those and similar questions must have some sort of f3tish for copyright, which is a very VERY broken system as it currently stands.
How about ventriloquists, some of whom can produce nearly indistinguishable voices from the person they're mimicking?

Would it be courteous to at least ask if these programs can be trained on certain works? Sure. If so, the above examples should have to ask as well; ventriloquists should have to ask Arnold Schwarzenegger before copying his voice for an act or Bugs Bunny before copying his voice. No, I'm not joking.
If you put a piece of art out for the public to see, hear, touch, experience and you (general) expect or worse, DEMAND them not to be inspired by it, you're (general) psychotic. Don't want people to be inspired by your work or ever create anything that clearly takes inspiration from your style, even if to show you how much they love your work, so much they wanted to emulate you, then don't make anything at all.
Like I said, blatant copying and claiming as your own is wrong. Fortunately, that's pretty impossible to do outside of digital media where copy/pasting is possible.

Concepts like copyright and intellectual property have no place in a modern society. They only slow us down in the end. We could make so much more progress if everything anyone ever creates, especially when it comes to medical research and technology, would be freely accessible to everyone. And people losing jobs/not being compensated should not be an issue either. The things necessary for a person to live a comfortable life should be basic human rights, not something you have to "earn". I want to live in a society where people work only when they want to work, when they are actually passionate about something. The concept of "earning a living" is all kinds of messed up.

I first encountered AI chat in the shape of an AI "therapist" in 1977. Having been in tech since those days, I have watched the evolution of many tools, AI included. The main problem lies not with AI but in the beliefs of its users. As a tech writer, I have learned to spot patterns (including being fairly reliable in identifying the native language of various writers writing in English). I can generally spot the patterns in AI text, and can trace its evolution, since I've watched it "grow up.". It's still essentially a probability generator. 
It has no concept of context. It does not distinguish Joe Smith the physicist from Joe Smith the dead cartoonist, and can mix and match. It literally does not know what "it" refers to. If I switch context, and "it" now refers to a cartoonist's works, it can hallucinate a reference. There is a case where a cybersecurity expert asked what chatGPT knew about him, and it replied with his obituary, and insisted he died in 2017. Even a nonfunctioning URL was furnished as a reference. But since it didn't know that a URL needed to point to collaborating information, it could not show where this information was obtained. But what if you are, say, a government entity who receives information that "you" are dead? You can see where this could go. (BTW, ask it to parse the "you" distinctions in those last two sentences.)
Our biggest dangers are human: the tendency to believe it "thinks" like a human and the tendency to believe its outputs without question.
About misinformation... well, the main media has been pushing it over 50 years at least..

As a content writer, I am already seeing it impact my work. Customers who don't care about the quality of the posts they put on their sites are using it to generate content much more cheaply than buying it from me. I do think it has its place in terms of a research aid, but it has decimated my small business. Hoping the ad revenue algorithms catch on eventually and clients will come back, but I'm not holding my breath at this point. Thanks for tackling this subject.

First of all I'd like to say good video from Ann as per usual. As an artist though, I'd like to give my 2 cents as this has been a major topic in the community.

First and foremost, I want to be clear that the AI in the format that it is now is unequivocally bad. The reason for this isnâ€™t because what a lot of people like to argue about in the news or social media or other places. Itâ€™s because as Ann touched on in her video, AI as it functions now is entirely built off theft and stolen work. People want to argue a lot about philosophy and what "art" really means and the human value of creating art and etc, but that is besides the main and primary issue that everything "generative AI" creates is 100% built on other artists' work, most often, *stolen* work which they are not compensated for.

Proponents of AI try so hard to dress up and hide this fact behind fancy buzzwords like "oh you just don't understand stable diffusion or machine learning or algorithms" or whatever other new thing it supposedly is that makes it not theft. But repeatedly several times, it is obvious to anyone with functioning eyes that supposedly "original" AI generated images are 1 to 1 matches with STOLEN artwork under copyright and nonconsensually taken without permission from the original artist. If you are doubtful please just look up examples on google and take a look  at side by side comparisons and it is boggling that people will even try to attempt to argue otherwise. Even giving benefit of the doubt, AI and computers do not do what you â€œwantâ€ them to do. AI and computers do what you *make* them to do, and whether consciously or not, they are 100% absolutely made to steal work from real human beings.

Let's be very clear, the AI is not "making" anything. It is fundamentally different from when a human artist takes inspiration from others. When it completely screws up hands with 6 fingers or makes weird flesh blobs of anatomy, why does it do that? Is it because the AI "thinks" that's what hands look like? Is it trying a new expressionist take on body horror and aesthetics? No, it's because it literally doesnâ€™t have the capacity to understand what a hand even is. When it puts gibberish scribbles in the corner of its image, is it because the AI is being cute and wants to â€œsignâ€ its work? No, it's because it doesn't know what a signature *is* and there are so many stolen pieces used to build it that it even tries to copy the signatures of the artists that it steals from!

The best analogy I have for it is imagining going to 2 baker's shops. You take 2 cakes (without paying btw), cut them in half, and then go "look everyone, look at this cake that *I* made" and then reselling the 2 cake halves to other people as an original work. Obviously people are going to look at that and call it nonsense because it's obvious that you just slapped together 2 other people's work. But then what happens if you do it with 4 bakers, and cut the cake into quarters? What about 10? 100? What about a million tiny slices cut and re-pieced into a Frankenstein cake? What if the slices become so small, that you cannot even tell with the human eye anymore?

Maybe you, a human being can't cut a cake into a million pieces to splice together, but a computer sure can. And that in short (though it is a bit more complicated than that) is exactly what AI "art" is doing. It does not â€œcreateâ€ anything new or original, it is 100% derivative of other artistsâ€™ work. And most notably, take into consideration how this business model is 100% unsustainable and impossible without taking other people's work that was already created - it cannot and does not actually "make" anything from scratch.

People want to argue about "taking inspiration" and "learning" as if the machine or AI is a person. But the fact of the matter is it's not. It's as simple as that. It does not have the capacity to learn and function like a person or create art like a person or "create" anything on its own, period. It is the fundamental difference of a person going to a bakery, discovering they like the way a baker makes a cake, then attempting to mix batter and bake the ingredients to recreate the cake they like vs the plagiarized Frankenstein cake scenario I explained above.

There is a saying in art that â€œeverything is derivativeâ€ in the sense that more or less everything in the art world is built from what came before it. Similarly in writing, itâ€™s not a coincidence that many stories contain many shared elements to the point we even have a term for it - tropes. In the musical western 12 tone scale, there are only so many combinations you can put those 12 notes to make a tune, and things like sampling are even welcomed and encouraged.

But there is a big difference in using samples in music or taking a general story structure of the heroâ€™s journey, or using tropes like found family or villain redemption arcs vs literally copy pasting other peopleâ€™s stories and characters into one you call your own using a thesaurus to change a few of the words, or tracing over another personâ€™s artwork and then calling it original, or splicing 8 other musical artistsâ€™ songs into 8 pieces then mashing them together and calling it a new song made by you.

To make derivative works transformative, you have to actually *do* something to make them different from the original art, thatâ€™s why things like remixes and covers can exist. But AI does not â€œdoâ€ or â€œcreateâ€ anything. No matter how many cakes you slice and mash together, you donâ€™t actually bake anything. Most notably, if those other bakers did not exist, your entire product, your AI â€œartwork" also would not exist. It is a shameless bastardization of an industry that solely relies on stealing the work of others in order to function.

And this is what separates from things like human art, music, or storytelling. Even without those who came before, even if Shakespeare did not exist, even if Da Vinci had never painted, people who came after can and will still find their own inspiration and create new and interesting work, even without literally taking from other artistsâ€™ products.

Without actual real artists to steal from, AI has nothing to offer. I firmly believe that copyright issues came somewhat as a red herring to divert eyes from the actual problems of AI. Just how you could spot issues with the recipe, I, as a programmer, can spot issues with generated code. AI is far from being intelligent. At best, on a human level, it is nothing but a people pleaser, and for anything other than the most basic things, a very bad one.

People think it's this magical app that will solve all of their problems, when in fact it might make the process worse, because even if you have to correct constantly, it doesn't mean that it's actually learning or that it will put that information to use, but instead it's just, again, saying what the person wants to hear. 

It's heavy dependance on the learning model also introduces a whole array of issues.. while it may be simpler in terms of art (whether written or drawn), in other aspects it often fails, because the material used isn't right. I've had mora than one occassion where I knew roughly how something in code is supposed to be, but wasn't too sure, and asked ChatGPT for that part. I did get my answer, but I got the most unoptimized, online course monkey code that I almost got offended looking at.

And in my opinion the biggest issue with this, just like with everything else, the easier something becomes more scum (collective for every person with malicious intent, be it those bots, "art thieves" or whatever) will use it for their own benefit. Before creating a game, or a script was hard and required professionals. Now if anyone can do it, anyone will. And anyone who wants to exploit something, now doesn't even have to be a professional in the field. And this will cause big problems for the general public who don't have the will or the time to check and verify everything they consume.. if it was an article they won't be able to tell apart genuine quality text from crap AI generated one. and an AI only needs to read a few to come up with something that sounds good.

For programmers, I believe the only viable method of using ChatGPT would be equal to asking a coworker. "Write me my today's tasks" won't do you any good, and nobody will say yes to that, but "Hey, can you remind me what the function for XY is?" can be a big help.

One major point that the American right wing kooks fail to observe is that A.I. cannot think for itself, and in particular it doesn't 'reason' using logic, rather it uses particular code to weigh different data points and combine them together in a novel manner.

Ask Chat GPT to prove a somewhat easy math theorem and it will usually produce something different than what was asked for, if it is even coherent. 

This is because it is not solving the problem, but rather it is searching for others who have solved the problem and copying what they've stated, but in a manner that combines different data points together rather than drawing from a single source. In the case of art or fictional literature, this is no issue. But when trying to produce a solid logical argument in this manner problems arise quickly.

The real risk of AI is that it won't matter whether the things it creates are good or not, all that will matter is the cost. We saw this years ago with how machine translation put countless translators out of work despite machine translation being abysmal in quality, because both regular people and billion-dollar companies alike would rather have awful work on the cheap than have good work that costs money.

That's without getting into the issues with what AI tools are actually being used for. One start-up promises that their revolutionary new AI tools can look at a video of a person giving a statement and detect whether they're lying or not. Needless to say, their tools cannot do any such thing (though they are significantly more likely to flag black people as lying, for some mysterious reason), but the startup's main customers are insurance companies looking for excuses to falsely accuse legit customers of lying so as to have an excuse to falsely deny valid insurance claims.

Human stories have meaning to us. We can use that to our advantage.

Sorry for correcting the information in the video. No AI application claims that they can diagnose a disease, e.g. , from a CT scan. The issue is the number of false-positives (cases where the AI say the disease exists while there is no disease in reality). False-positives do no harm when it comes to generation of arts and texts. But when it comes to health it can have dramatic outcomes. AI is still far far away from being able to find diseases with certainty. What AI can do is to help medical professionals make a decision.

To me it makes sense that if an AI generated piece of artworkâ€“ written or visualâ€“ is just being used for personal entertainment in a private setting, then it poses no threat to genuine creators, since people often don't pay for images they copy and save.
But if an image is going to be sold, or used in advertising, or monetised in some other way, then the authors of whatever copyrighted materials were used to train the AI should be paid a proportional amount of royalties.
I've heard some object to this and argue that the AI process of absorbing a lot of artistic material and producing something roughly akin to it is really no different than how artistic inspiration works with people. I don't really buy this, because AI is obviously just a collection of code and can't produce anything as a form of genuine artistic self-expression. If you had an AI in the distant future that *could* express genuine artistic intentionâ€“ and there's a lot of science fiction written about just such an eventualityâ€“ then that would mean it's experiencing real emotion and free will as a non-human person, and it should therefore be paid a fair wage for its creative work to spend how it likes... thus defeating the financial advantage of even using AI.
